questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive left leg pain for the past 2 months, which has started to interfere with his sleep. His mother has been giving him ibuprofen at night for “growing pains,” but his symptoms have not improved. One week before the pain started, the patient was hit in the thigh by a baseball, which caused his leg to become red and swollen for several days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows marked tenderness along the left mid-femur. His gait is normal. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 68 mm/h. An x-ray of the left lower extremity shows multiple lytic lesions in the middle third of the femur, and the surrounding cortex is covered by several layers of new bone. A biopsy of the left femur shows small round blue cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteosarcoma typically occurs in the long bones of individuals between 10–20 years of age and presents similarly, with painful swelling and progressive symptoms over the course of a few weeks to months. However, osteosarcoma usually arises at the metaphysis, has a mixed lytic-sclerotic appearance, and involves an aggressive periosteal reaction with perpendicular new bone growth (resulting in a sunburst pattern and/or Codman's triangle) and irregular cortical destruction. A biopsy would reveal poorly formed trabecular bone.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP and lateral views) of a patient with osteosarcoma

An ill-defined cloud-like lesion with a wide zone of transition (green overlay) is seen in the distal femur. An aggressive type of periosteal reaction known as a Codman triangle (C) is visible medially. Additional aggressive periosteal reaction seen posteriorly has produced a sunburst pattern (S).

B) INCORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma appears as a focal osteolytic lesion on x-ray and may present with painful swelling. However, chondrosarcoma is extremely rare in patients < 30 years old and classically involves the pelvis, the proximal femur, or the proximal humerus. An x-ray would also show characteristic ring-and-arc or popcorn calcifications. A biopsy would show hyaline cartilage with a chondroid matrix and atypical binucleated cells.
Image Description:

X-ray hips (AP view) of patient with left hip pain, swelling, gait instability, and restriction of movement

A mixed lytic and blastic lesion in the left hemipelvis is accompanied by a large soft tissue component. Indistinct margins and areas of cortical destruction suggest an aggressive lesion.

Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteochondroma typically presents as a painless bone swelling in the metaphyses of long bones, rather than the diaphysis as seen here. An x-ray would reveal a metaphyseal bony protrusion with variable degrees of sclerosis and a cartilaginous cap.
Image Description:

Bony exostosis on the lateral right distal tibial metaphysis and deformation of the right fibula

D) INCORRECT:

Chondroblastoma typically affects patients < 20 years old, appears as a lytic lesion in a long bone on x-ray, and may present with pain and swelling due to associated edema. However, chondroblastoma almost always occurs in the epiphysis and appears as single lytic lesions with well-defined margins that typically have a solid periosteal reaction (unlike the multiple diaphyseal lytic lesions and lamellated periosteal reaction seen here). Symptoms are more indolent and progress slowly over a period of 1–2 years. A biopsy would show a bluish chondroid matrix and a characteristic “chicken-wire” calcification, which is caused by calcium deposition around the chondroblasts.
Image Description:

X-ray of the right talocrural joint (a. AP view; b. lateral view)

An oval osteolytic lesion is visible in the posterolateral part of the distal tibial epiphysis.

This is the typical appearance of chondroblastoma.

E) CORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma typically occurs in patients < 20 years of age and involves the diaphysis of long bones. An x-ray usually reveals a tumor with multiple lytic lesions that may extend into the surrounding soft tissue and an aggressive lamellated periosteal reaction, giving rise to the classic onion skin appearance on x-ray (see “Overview of primary malignant bone tumors” table). A biopsy reveals small, round undifferentiated cells that appear dark blue on an H&E stain because these cells have a large nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, and the nucleus stains blue with hematoxylin. Patients also often have systemic features such as fever, ↑ ESR, and leukocytosis. A t(11;22) chromosomal translocation is found in approximately 90% of cases of Ewing sarcoma, resulting in expression of fusion protein EWS-FLI 1.
Image Description:

X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcoma

A lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

F) INCORRECT:

Osteoid osteoma typically affects patients < 30 years old in the diaphysis of a long bone and typically presents with nocturnal pain. However, an x-ray would usually show a single lytic nidus (< 2 cm in size) surrounded by a dense sclerotic reaction (unlike the multiple lytic lesions and lamellated periosteal reaction seen here). Also, pain would be relieved dramatically by aspirin or NSAIDs such as ibuprofen (since pain is caused by prostaglandins produced in the nidus).
Image Description:

X-ray right hip (AP view) of a 12-year-old boy

A small lucent nidus (hatched green overlay) in the medial proximal femur is accompanied by reactive sclerosis and cortical thickening (green overlay).

The appearance is compatible with osteoid osteoma, although other conditions (e.g., intracortical abscess, stress fracture, osteoblastoma) can mimic osteoid osteoma and must be distinguished on the basis of the clinical presentation and additional imaging.
questions.hint: Genetic testing of the biopsy sample will likely reveal a t(11;22) chromosomal translocation.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive right knee pain for the past 3 months. He reports that the pain is worse at night and while doing sports at school. He has not had any trauma to the knee or any previous problems with his joints. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee shows mild swelling and tenderness without warmth or erythema; the range of motion is limited. He walks with an antalgic gait. Laboratory studies show an alkaline phosphatase of 180 U/L and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 80 mm/h. An x-ray of the right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteoclastoma may also manifest with pain and swelling of a long bone, but it usually occurs in patients 20–40 years of age. Although the tumor may be located in the metaphysis, as in this patient, the epiphysis is typically involved, with the tumor lying in close proximity to the articular surface. An x-ray would also reveal a large, expansile lytic lesion with a thin layer of cortex and a loculated or “soap-bubble” appearance within the tumor due to trabecular remnants. The periosteal reaction would also not be as aggressive as what is seen in this patient's x-ray.
Image Description:

X-ray left knee (AP view) of a 23-year-old patient with a giant cell tumor (osteoclastoma)

A lucent lesion in the proximal tibia (green overlay) has a bubbly appearance (examples indicated by outlines) and well-defined nonsclerotic margins. The cortex shows endosteal scalloping (examples indicated by arrowheads). The growth plate is closed and the lesion extends to the subarticular bone.

Giant cell tumor is one of several bone lesions that can have a bubbly appearance. Most giant cell tumors are eccentrically located, although large lesions may appear central. They are typically located at the ends of the long bones in the region of the closed growth plate. Some giant cell tumors contain aneurysmal bone cyst components.

B) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma occurs in patients younger than 20 years of age and manifests similarly, with painful swelling that is exacerbated at night, increased ESR, increased alkaline phosphatase, and an aggressive periosteal reaction. However, the tumor typically occurs in the diaphysis of long bones, and an x-ray would reveal a tumor with multiple lytic lesions and a lamellated periosteal reaction (giving rise to an onion skin appearance on x-ray), in contrast to the mixed lytic-sclerotic lesion with a sunburst periosteal reaction.
Image Description:

X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcoma

A lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

C) INCORRECT:

Chordoma is typically seen in the axial skeleton of patients older than 50 years. The onset of symptoms is more indolent (usually occurring over a few years), and patients present with back or neck pain and/or slowly progressive neurological deficits. An x-ray would reveal a well-defined lytic lesion with marginal sclerosis and calcifications within the tumor (due to bony sequestrations).

D) INCORRECT:

Osteochondroma is the most common primary benign bone tumor. While it is more common among males 10–20 years of age, it typically manifests as a painless bone swelling near the ends of long bones. Inflammatory markers, such as ESR, are usually not increased. An x-ray would reveal a bony protrusion with variable degrees of sclerosis and a cartilaginous cap.
Image Description:

X-ray of the right upper arm

Patchy, calcified, mushroom-shaped exostosis on the surface of the humerus.
Displacement of the adjacent soft tissue (arrows) without infiltration (sharp demarcation).

E) INCORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma also often occurs in the metaphysis of long bones such as the femur and may manifest as a painful swelling. However, chondrosarcoma usually occurs in patients older than 50 years. An x-ray typically shows a focal osteolytic lesion with characteristic ring and arcs or popcorn calcifications and/or endosteal scalloping.
Image Description:

X-ray hips (AP view) of patient with left hip pain, swelling, gait instability, and restriction of movement

A mixed lytic and blastic lesion in the left hemipelvis is accompanied by a large soft tissue component. Indistinct margins and areas of cortical destruction suggest an aggressive lesion.

Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma.

F) CORRECT:

Osteosarcoma typically occurs in adolescents and young adults and involves the metaphysis of long bones. Patients present with swelling and pain that is worse at night and during activity. Decreased range of motion and gait abnormalities are also common. X-ray usually reveals a poorly defined lytic-sclerotic tumor at the metaphysis with irregular cortical destruction and an aggressive periosteal reaction with perpendicular new bone growth, resulting in a sunburst pattern and/or Codman triangle (see “Overview of primary malignant bone tumors” table). Alkaline phosphatase is often elevated in patients with osteosarcoma and is considered a poor prognostic marker.

The initial workup of this patient involves a contrast-enhanced MRI of the affected bone followed by a core needle or surgical biopsy for histological diagnosis. A chest CT, as well as a PET scan or a bone scan, should be performed to look for metastases. Definitive therapy consists of wide surgical resection of the tumor.
questions.hint: This patient's age and the location and radiological features of his bone lesion raise concern for the most common primary bone malignancy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of worsening pain in his left buttock. The pain is described as a deep, dull ache that is worse at night. He does not report any recent trauma. He has hyperlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks one beer every night. His only medication is simvastatin. Physical examination shows tenderness over the left gluteal region. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. The remainder of the physical examination, including rectal examination, shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a 4-cm, poorly defined, osteolytic lesion in the left ilium with a moth-eaten pattern of bone destruction, multiple well-defined sclerotic lesions, and an aggressive periosteal reaction. Chest x-ray and abdominal ultrasonography show no abnormalities. A biopsy specimen of the pelvic lesion shows moderate cellularity with a lobulated appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteosarcomas, which are the most common nonhematological primary bone malignancies, can affect any site, including the pelvis, and appear on x-ray as a mixed lytic-sclerotic lesion with an aggressive periosteal reaction (classically sunburst appearance and Codman triangle). Nighttime pain is also a characteristic feature of osteosarcomas. However, primary osteosarcomas have a peak incidence during the second decade of life, and the metaphyses of long bones (typically the distal femur, proximal tibia, or proximal humerus) are more commonly affected than flat bones (e.g., the ilium). While osteosarcoma cannot be entirely excluded in this patient without histopathological evaluation, the patient's age and the location of the lesion make another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP and lateral views) of a patient with osteosarcoma

An ill-defined cloud-like lesion with a wide zone of transition (green overlay) is seen in the distal femur. An aggressive type of periosteal reaction known as a Codman triangle (C) is visible medially. Additional aggressive periosteal reaction seen posteriorly has produced a sunburst pattern (S).

B) INCORRECT:

A giant cell tumor of the bone (osteoclastoma) can cause progressively worsening pain and appear on x-ray as an osteolytic lesion. However, osteoclastoma appears in individuals 20–40 years of age, affects the epiphyseal/metaphyseal region of the long bones (e.g., distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius), and typically shows up on x-ray as a well-defined, soap-bubble-like lesion with a nonaggressive periosteal reaction. Involvement of the axial skeleton is uncommon, and sclerosis within the lesion would not be expected.
Image Description:

X-ray left knee (AP view) of a 23-year-old patient with a giant cell tumor (osteoclastoma)

A lucent lesion in the proximal tibia (green overlay) has a bubbly appearance (examples indicated by outlines) and well-defined nonsclerotic margins. The cortex shows endosteal scalloping (examples indicated by arrowheads). The growth plate is closed and the lesion extends to the subarticular bone.

Giant cell tumor is one of several bone lesions that can have a bubbly appearance. Most giant cell tumors are eccentrically located, although large lesions may appear central. They are typically located at the ends of the long bones in the region of the closed growth plate. Some giant cell tumors contain aneurysmal bone cyst components.

C) INCORRECT:

A plasmacytoma, the most common primary bone malignancy in patients above the age of 40 years, can involve the pelvis and present as a painful osteolytic lesion. However, a plasmacytoma would characteristically appear as a well-defined, punched-out lesion, in contrast to the poorly defined lesion with a moth-eaten pattern of bone destruction seen in this patient. Moreover, sclerosis within the lesion would not be expected, and a periosteal reaction is typically absent.
Image Description:

X-ray knee (AP oblique and lateral views) of a patient with a history of POEMS syndrome

An expansile lesion (green overlay) in the metaphysis of the distal femur shows a mixed, predominantly lytic pattern. The lesion involves both trabecular and cortical bone and is accompanied by some periosteal reaction (red overlay).

Biopsy confirmed a plasmacytoma. Of note, plasmacytomas in POEMS syndrome are typically sclerotic lesions.

D) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma can affect the flat bones (e.g., the ilium) and present similarly with pain in the buttock, an osteolytic lesion on x-ray, and an aggressive periosteal reaction (classically an onion-peel appearance). However, sclerotic lesions are not seen in Ewing sarcoma. Moreover, Ewing sarcoma typically occurs before the age of 30 years (peak incidence: 10–15 years) and more commonly involves the diaphyses of long bones (typically the femur, tibia, fibula or humerus).
Image Description:

X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcoma

A lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

E) INCORRECT:

An osteochondroma is a benign, slow-growing primary bone tumor that is usually asymptomatic and discovered as an incidental finding on imaging. It occurs on the metaphysis of long bones (typically the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus) and would characteristically appear as a small bony protrusion, in contrast to the poorly defined lesion with a moth-eaten pattern of bone destruction seen in this patient.
Image Description:

X-ray of the right upper arm

Patchy, calcified, mushroom-shaped exostosis on the surface of the humerus.
Displacement of the adjacent soft tissue (arrows) without infiltration (sharp demarcation).

F) CORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma is the second most common nonhematological primary bone malignancy. Primary chondrosarcoma typically affects the pelvis, proximal femur, or proximal humerus of individuals 50–70 years of age and manifests with progressively worsening pain. A swelling can occasionally be palpated but may not be readily apparent in all patients, especially those with pelvic or proximal femoral involvement. On x-ray, chondrosarcomas appear as osteolytic lesions with a moth-eaten or permeative pattern of bone destruction and spiculated, popcorn-like, or ring-and-arc sclerosis, which are characteristic of chondroid matrix calcification (see “Overview of primary malignant bone tumors” table). Other radiological features include an aggressive periosteal reaction and endosteal scalloping. Biopsy typically shows cartilaginous growth with nodular architecture.

Secondary chondrosarcomas, which typically arise from malignant degeneration of osteochondromas and enchondromas or occur in patients with Paget disease of bone, are more common in younger patients (20–30 years of age).
Image Description:

X-ray of the pelvis (AP view)

Osteolytic zone in the left acetabulum (green overlay).
questions.hint: This patient's age and the location of the lesion are typical for this type of bone tumor.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of severe right hip pain. The pain is worse at night. He has chronic headaches and back pain for which he takes vitamin D, calcium supplements, and ibuprofen. Examination shows hip tenderness and mild sensorineural hearing loss. X-ray of the hip shows a radiolucent lesion in the ilium with a moth-eaten appearance, wide transition zone, and an aggressive periosteal reaction. Wide excision of the lesion is performed. A photomicrograph of a section of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma commonly affects the axial skeleton (including the pelvis), has a peak incidence at 50–70 years, and would cause radiolucent lesions on x-ray. This patient's history of chronic back pain, chronic headaches (skull involvement), and hearing loss (SNHL) are also consistent with the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. However, multiple myeloma would appear as well-defined (narrow transition zone) lesions on x-ray with a punched-out appearance and minimal periosteal reaction. Furthermore, biopsy of a multiple myeloma lesion would show numerous plasma cells, which are not seen here.
Image Description:

Bone marrow aspirate smear (May-Gruenwald stain; high magnification)

An increased density of plasma cells is visible. Plasma cells possess a round eccentric nucleus (example indicated by yellow hatched overlay) with clock-face chromatin (example indicated by white circle) and a perinuclear halo (perinuclear hof; example indicated by white overlay). Other cell types present include neutrophils (example indicated by blue overlay), lymphocytes (examples indicated by black arrowheads), and erythrocytes (example indicated by blue hatched overlay).
Additionally, the plasma cells in this specimen show features of atypia, e.g., multinucleated cells (example indicated by yellow outline), prominent nucleoli (example indicated by yellow arrowhead), and enlarged as well as irregularly shaped cytoplasm (example indicated by yellow overlay).

The diagnosis of multiple myeloma requires the lesion to consist of monoclonal plasma cells, which is confirmed by kappa or lambda light chain restriction.

B) INCORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma is associated with PDB, often affects the pelvis, can appear as an ill-defined (wide transition zone), radiolucent lesion with a moth-eaten appearance and aggressive periosteal reaction, and show eosinophilic cartilaginous matrix on biopsy, as seen here. However, the biopsy of a chondrosarcoma would also show nests of small, round, anaplastic cartilage cells with a pathognomonic chicken wire mesh appearance, and an x-ray would typically reveal ring-and-arc or popcorn-like calcification within the tumor. These features are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

Blue overlays: examples of calcifications; yellow outlines: examples of lobulations; arrowheads: examples of enlarged nuclei

C) CORRECT:

Osteosarcoma is the most common bone malignancy associated with PDB. Osteosarcomas have immature osteoid, which appears as eosinophilic, glassy material around pleomorphic tumor cells. Destruction of normal bone results in an osteolytic (radiolucent) lesion with an ill-defined border (wide transition zone) and a moth-eaten appearance. Aggressive periosteal reactions (e.g., sunburst appearance, Codman triangle) indicate lifting of the periosteum following rapid tumor growth. Other risk factors for developing osteosarcomas are bone infarcts, radiation, retinoblastoma gene mutations, and Li-Fraumeni syndrome.

Secondary osteosarcomas, which develop in diseased bone, typically manifest in older individuals. In contrast, primary osteosarcomas, which develop in previously normal bone, have a peak incidence at 10–20 years of age, with metaphyses of long bones (typically the distal femur, proximal tibia) more commonly affected than flat bones (e.g., the ilium).

D) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma can occur in flat bones such as the ilium and appear as an ill-defined (wide transition zone), radiolucent lesion with a moth-eaten appearance and an aggressive periosteal reaction (e.g., a lamellated “onion-skin” reaction). However, a biopsy would have shown nests of anaplastic small blue cells (primitive neuroectodermal cells) arranged around capillaries (pseudorosettes). Moreover, Ewing sarcoma is not a complication of PDB, which this patient has.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) INCORRECT:

A giant cell tumor of the bone (osteoclastoma), which is a rare complication of PDB, can present as a radiolucent lesion and show multinucleated cells on biopsy, as seen here. However, the multinucleated cells would be larger (giant cells) and contain many more nuclei (typically > 50), and other pathognomic features such as a highly vascular stroma as well as sheets of mononuclear cells would be present. Moreover, osteoclastomas typically affect the epiphyseal regions of long bones, rather than flat bones like the ilium, and an x-ray would show a well-defined (narrow transition zone) lesion with a non-aggressive periosteal reaction and a soap-bubble appearance.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a section from a bone tumor biopsy (H&E stain)

Numerous giant cells containing multiple nuclei are visible throughout the image (examples indicated by yellow overlay). These cells are surrounded by a hypercellular stroma composed of mononuclear cells (examples indicated by black arrowheads).

These features are typical of giant-cell tumors of the bone.
questions.hint: This patient likely has Paget disease of the bone (PDB), which, when symptomatic, manifests with nonspecific features such as bone pain. The sensorineural hearing loss is likely due to bony compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve. Chronically increased bone turnover in patients with long-standing PDB increases the risk of a certain bone malignancy.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-month history of pain in his right leg. His mother has been giving him ketorolac at night to improve his sleep, but the pain has not improved. Physical examination shows marked tenderness along the right mid-femur. An x-ray of the right lower extremity shows several lytic lesions in the diaphysis of the femur and a surrounding cortex covered by several layers of new bone. A biopsy of the right femur shows small round blue cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma typically occurs in patients < 20 years of age and involves the diaphysis of long bones. X-ray usually reveals a tumor with multiple lytic lesions that may extend into the surrounding soft tissue and an aggressive lamellated periosteal reaction. A biopsy shows small blue cells with a high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio. Systemic symptoms, as seen in this patient, are common. A t(11;22) chromosomal translocation, resulting in expression of fusion protein EWS-FLI 1, is found in approx. 90% of cases of Ewing sarcoma.
Image Description:

X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcoma

A lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

B) INCORRECT:

While this patient's age, x-ray findings, and local symptoms would fit the diagnosis of chondroblastoma, this condition almost always occurs in the epiphysis and manifests as a single lytic lesion with well-defined margins. Symptoms are less severe and progress more slowly (over a period of 1–2 years) than those experienced by this patient. A biopsy would show a bluish chondroid matrix and a characteristic chicken-wire calcification pattern.

C) INCORRECT:

An osteochondroma typically presents as a painless bone swelling in the metaphyses of long bones, rather than the diaphysis as seen here. X-ray would reveal a metaphyseal bony protrusion with variable degrees of sclerosis and a cartilaginous cap. Unlike in this patient, a biopsy of osteochondroma would typically show abundant cartilage matrix with irregular lobules and fibrous band formation.
Image Description:

Bony exostosis on the lateral right distal tibial metaphysis and deformation of the right fibula

D) INCORRECT:

Osteosarcomas typically occur in the long bones of adolescents between 10–20 years of age and present with painful swelling and progressive symptoms over the course of a few weeks to months similar to those experienced by this patient. However, they usually arise at the metaphysis, have a mixed lytic-sclerotic appearance, and involve an aggressive periosteal reaction with perpendicular new bone growth and irregular cortical destruction. A biopsy would reveal poorly formed trabecular bone.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP and lateral views) of a patient with osteosarcoma

An ill-defined cloud-like lesion with a wide zone of transition (green overlay) is seen in the distal femur. An aggressive type of periosteal reaction known as a Codman triangle (C) is visible medially. Additional aggressive periosteal reaction seen posteriorly has produced a sunburst pattern (S).

E) INCORRECT:

A chondrosarcoma appears as a focal osteolytic lesion on x-ray with characteristic ring-and-arc calcifications and may present with painful swelling. However, chondrosarcomas are extremely rare in patients < 30 years of age and would classically involve the pelvis, not the diaphysis of the femur. A biopsy would reveal hyaline cartilage with a chondroid matrix and atypical binucleate cells.
Image Description:

X-ray hips (AP view) of patient with left hip pain, swelling, gait instability, and restriction of movement

A mixed lytic and blastic lesion in the left hemipelvis is accompanied by a large soft tissue component. Indistinct margins and areas of cortical destruction suggest an aggressive lesion.

Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Osteoid osteomas typically affect patients < 30 years old in the diaphysis of a long bone and manifest with nocturnal pain, as seen here. However, x-ray would usually show a single lytic nidus surrounded by a dense sclerotic reaction. Unlike in this patient, the pain of osteoid osteoma would be responsive to NSAIDs such as ketorolac.
questions.hint: Further diagnostics will likely reveal a t(11;22) chromosomal translocation.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive left leg pain for the past 2 months. The pain is worse while running and at night. Examination of the left leg shows swelling and tenderness proximal to the knee. Laboratory studies show an alkaline phosphatase level of 200 U/L. An x-ray of the left leg shows sclerosis, cortical destruction, and new bone formation in the soft tissues around the distal femur. There are multiple spiculae radiating perpendicular to the bone. This patient's malignancy is most likely derived from cells in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Osteosarcomas are caused by malignant osteoblasts that arise from mesenchymal stem cells located within the periosteum. In patients with osteosarcoma, malignant osteoblast activity results in increased production of osteoid matrix and formation of poorly organized bone networks. Osteosarcomas can destroy nearby structures and cause periosteal reactions, which may manifest with the characteristic Codman triangle and/or sunburst appearance on imaging.
Image Description:

X-ray knee (lateral view) of an 18 year-old patient with pain

A mixed lytic and sclerotic lesion showing a permeative pattern of destruction involves the distal femoral metaphysis and metadiaphysis. It is accompanied by a Codman triangle with aggressive periosteal reaction that extends into the soft tissues.

Although biopsy is required for a definitive diagnosis, the location and appearance of the lesion in combination with the patient's age suggest osteosarcoma. The distal femur is a particularly common location for osteosarcoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Malignancies arising from the bone marrow can originate from various hematopoietic cells to form distinct neoplastic diseases (e.g., acute and chronic leukemia, multiple myeloma). The most common pediatric malignancy, ALL, can cause insidious bone pain similar to this patient's symptoms. However, leukemias would not present with the radiographic findings seen in this patient. Moreover, this boy lacks other common findings of acute leukemia, such as splenomegaly, anemia, hemorrhage, and/or history of recurrent infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Tumors arising from chondroblasts of cartilage tissue are known as enchondromas (benign) and chondrosarcomas (malignant). Both types of cartilage-derived tumors can present with bone pain and local swelling. However, they would not present with elevated alkaline phosphatase levels or periosteal reactions on x-ray. Moreover, chondrosarcomas commonly present with osteolytic lesions involving the pelvis, spine, or shoulder girdle and mainly occur in patients over the age of 50 years.
Image Description:

X-ray hips (AP view) of patient with left hip pain, swelling, gait instability, and restriction of movement

A mixed lytic and blastic lesion in the left hemipelvis is accompanied by a large soft tissue component. Indistinct margins and areas of cortical destruction suggest an aggressive lesion.

Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Giant cell tumors of bone are benign, locally aggressive tumors that arise from osteoclastic, multinucleated giant cells (due to overactivity in the RANK signaling pathway) in the epiphysis of long bones. Giant cell tumors usually arise around the knee and present with local pain and swelling, as seen here. However, unlike in this 15-year-old boy, these tumors typically occur in patients older than 20 years and appear on x-ray as a well-defined osteolytic lesion with a soap-bubble appearance.

E) INCORRECT:

Neuroblastoma are malignant, neuroendocrine tumors that originate from neural crest cells and most commonly present in early childhood. Neuroblastomas can occur anywhere along the sympathetic tract and can metastasize to the bone, causing localized pain and swelling. Unlike the findings in this patient, these metastases would appear as lytic lesions on x-ray. Moreover, this patient lacks other common findings of neuroblastoma, such as abdominal distention and hypertension.
questions.hint: This boy presents with a tender swelling of his knee, elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, and an x-ray showing a Codman triangle (protrusion that extends from the primary site) and sunburst appearance (formation of spicules). Given his age, he most likely has osteosarcoma.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of upper back pain. The pain is severe, dull in quality, and worse during the night. Physical examination shows a lump in the lower lateral quadrant of the right breast. Examination of the back shows tenderness over the thoracic spinous processes. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the thoracic spine shows vertebral osteolytic lesions at the levels of T4 and T5. A biopsy of the breast lump confirms the diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma. The patient's thoracic spine lesions are most likely a result of metastatic spread via which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The internal mammary lymph nodes (parasternal lymph nodes) receive lymph from the medial quadrants of the breast and only receive 10–25% of the breast's lymphatic drainage. Lymph from this patient's breast tumor, which is located in the lower lateral quadrant, would most likely drain into the axillary lymph nodes. Moreover, lymphatic spread is not the most common route of metastatic spread from the breast to the spine.
Image Description:

Lymphatics of the breast drain into three groups:

1. Axillary group, further divided into three levels
– Level I: lateral to the lateral border of the pectoralis minor
– Level II: behind the pectoralis minor
– Level III: medial to the medial border of the pectoralis minor
2. Parasternal (internal thoracic) group
3. Posterior intercostal group (not shown here)

Efferent lymphatics travel to the supraclavicular nodes and terminate in the thoracic duct (on the left; not shown here) or the right lymphatic duct.

B) CORRECT:

Blood from the breast drains into the ipsilateral intercostal veins. The azygos vein receives blood from the right posterior intercostal veins. The azygos vein has numerous anastomoses with the vertebral venous plexus, which is a longitudinal network of valveless veins in the spine that includes the paravertebral plexus of Batson. The lack of valves in this network facilitates the spread of tumors and infections. Spinal metastases from breast cancer most commonly develop in the thoracic vertebrae. A similar route via the internal iliac vein, which connects the prostatic venous plexus with the vertebral venous plexus, is responsible for metastasis from prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae. Most carcinomas tend to metastasize lymphatically but bone metastases (especially spinal metastases) are most commonly the result of hematogenous spread rather than lymphatic spread.
Image Description:

Chest, neck, and abdomen (coronal section, ventral view)

The veins depicted here ultimately drain into the superior and the inferior vena cava.

C) INCORRECT:

The thyrocervical trunk arises from the subclavian artery and gives rise to the inferior thyroid artery, suprascapular artery, transverse cervical artery, and ascending cervical artery. The thyrocervical trunk is a potential route for metastasis of lung cancer to the scapula (via the suprascapular artery) and cervical vertebrae (via the ascending cervical artery) but is not a potential route for metastasis of breast cancer to the thoracic spine.
Image Description:

Ventral view

The left subclavian artery arises directly from the arch of aorta. The right subclavian artery arises from the brachiocephalic artery. At the outer border of the first rib, the subclavian arteries continue as the axillary arteries. The main branches of the subclavian artery (from proximal to distal) are:
- Internal thoracic artery (internal mammary artery)
- Vertebral artery
- Thyrocervical trunk
- Costocervical trunk

D) INCORRECT:

The thoracic duct (left lymphatic duct), which receives lymphatic drainage from the left axillary lymph nodes and drains into the left subclavian vein, is a potential route for pulmonary metastasis in the case of left-sided breast carcinoma but it is not a likely route for metastasis of right-sided breast cancer. Moreover, lymphatic spread is not the most common route of metastatic spread from the breast to the spine.
Image Description:

Lymph is drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct primarily drains the upper right side of the body (green overlay). The thoracic duct is responsible for draining the rest of the body.

Testicular tumors do not typically disseminate to scrotal lymph nodes, because the two organs have separate lymphatic systems: testes drain to the para-aortic nodes and the scrotum drains to superficial inguinal nodes.

E) INCORRECT:

The anterior intercostal arteries (branches of the ipsilateral internal thoracic artery) and posterior intercostal arteries (branches of the thoracic aorta) are potential routes for metastasis of lung cancer to structures of the thoracic wall (e.g., ribs); they are not routes for metastasis of breast cancer to the thoracic spine.
Image Description:

Illustration of the intercostal artery, vein, and nerve (forming the intercostal neurovascular bundle) within the costal groove

As the pathway of these structures follows the inferior edge of the ribs, medical interventions (e.g., chest tube insertion) are always performed along the superior edge of the rib. The order of the structures of the neurovascular bundle can be remembered using the acronym “VAN”: the intercostal vein (V) is superior, the artery (A) is in the middle, and the nerve (N) is inferior.
questions.hint: This patient has metastatic lesions in the vertebrae due to spread of her breast cancer to a structure that communicates with the paravertebral plexus of Batson.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of undulating, dull pain in his right thigh. Physical examination shows a tender, round mass located above the right knee on the anterior aspect of the thigh. An x-ray of the right thigh shows sunburst pattern of osteolytic bone lesions in combination with sclerotic bone formation and invasion of the surrounding tissue. Despite limb-sparing attempts, the patient has to undergo amputation of the right leg. A photograph of a cross-section of the affected leg is shown. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Paget disease of bone (PDB) is strongly associated with the development of osteosarcoma. Increased RANK/RANKL activity leads to an increase in osteoclast activity and subsequently to an increase in osteoblast activity, which induces remodeling of the bone. This results in weaker, disorganized bone tissue that is predisposed to malignant degeneration (sarcomatous transformation). Other risk factors for secondary osteosarcoma include Li Fraumeni syndrome, radiation injury, and extensive bone infarcts.

Primary osteosarcomas typically occur in the long bones of individuals between 10–25 years of age.
Image Description:

X-ray knee (lateral view) of an 18 year-old patient with pain

A mixed lytic and sclerotic lesion showing a permeative pattern of destruction involves the distal femoral metaphysis and metadiaphysis. It is accompanied by a Codman triangle with aggressive periosteal reaction that extends into the soft tissues.

Although biopsy is required for a definitive diagnosis, the location and appearance of the lesion in combination with the patient's age suggest osteosarcoma. The distal femur is a particularly common location for osteosarcoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Gardner syndrome is a subtype of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) that involves the formation of extracolonic tumors such as osteomas. These benign bone tumors are frequently seen on the skull and mandible but rarely in the metaphyses of long bones. Moreover, this patient has no other symptoms of Gardner syndrome (hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium, adrenal adenomas, desmoid tumors, or cutaneous lesions).

C) INCORRECT:

A t(11;22) translocation results in the production of the fusion protein EWS-FLI-1, which predisposes patients to Ewing sarcoma, a malignant bone tumor of neuroectodermal cells. However, Ewing sarcoma tends to occur in the diaphysis, not the metaphyses of long bones. Moreover, x-rays would classically show “onion-skinning” but not a sunburst pattern.
Image Description:

X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcoma

A lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

D) INCORRECT:

Severe hyperparathyroidism is associated with osteitis fibrosa cystica, which often involves the formation of brown tumors. These tumors consist of osteoclast clusters within a mixture of fibrous tissue and woven bone and are high in hemosiderin (giving the lesions a brown color). However, this patient shows none of the typical signs of hyperparathyroidism (hypercalcemia, renal stones, polyuria, constipation, or psychiatric disturbances).

E) INCORRECT:

FGF receptor mutations, which produce activated fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3), are the cause of achondroplasia. Overactive FGFR3 prevents endochondral ossification and prevents longitudinal bone growth. This mutation is the most common cause of dwarfism. However, this patient does not present with dwarfism.

F) INCORRECT:

Tuberous sclerosis is a strong risk factor for the development of chordomas. These slow-growing malignant bone tumors tend to manifest in regions developmentally related to the notochord (e.g., the skull, vertebral bodies, and sacrococcygeal region) and are not normally found in the metaphyses of long bones. However, this patient has no signs of tuberous sclerosis (intellectual disability, seizures, typical skin manifestations like ash-leaf spots or Shagreen patches).
questions.hint: An osteoid-producing bone tumor with a sunburst pattern on x-ray suggests osteosarcoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 7-month history of dull hip pain that worsens at night. Treatment with over-the-counter ibuprofen has not lessened the pain. He has not had any trauma to the hip. Examination shows swelling and marked tenderness to palpation over the right hip. An x-ray of the right hip shows an ill-defined lytic lesion with spiculated calcifications and soft tissue infiltration in the proximal femur. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteoblastoma is a benign bone tumor that can manifest with progressive, dull pain that is unresponsive to NSAID therapy. However, osteoblastomas develop more commonly in the vertebrae than the pelvis. In addition, osteoblastomas usually develop in children and young adults (peak incidence of 10–20 years of age). Moreover, x-ray findings typically show a bony mass with a radiolucent core, which is not seen here. Infiltration of the adjacent soft tissue, as seen in this patient, would not be expected.
Image Description:

X-ray cervical spine (lateral view) and CT cervical spine (bone window; axial plane)

An expansile mixed lytic and sclerotic lesion involves the right C7 posterior elements (green overlay). The epicenter is in the region of the right lateral mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor that can manifest with progressive pain that worsens at night. However, these tumors typically develop in the cortices of long bones rather than the pelvis, and the associated pain is usually relieved by NSAID therapy. In addition, osteoid osteomas usually develop in children and young adults (peak incidence of 10–30 years of age). Moreover, x-ray findings typically show a bony mass with a radiolucent core, which is not seen here. Infiltration of the adjacent soft tissue, as seen in this patient, would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that arises from the growth plate. Although this tumor can cause pain, it is typically asymptomatic. Because osteochondromas most commonly develop during periods of rapid bone growth, they are more common in children and adolescents (peak incidence of 10–20 years of age) than adults. In addition, they usually develop in the metaphyses of long bones rather than the pelvis. Moreover, x-ray findings typically show a pedunculated or sessile lesion on the surface of bone metaphyses, neither of which is seen here. Infiltration of the adjacent soft tissue, as seen in this patient, would not be expected.
Image Description:

X-ray of the femur of a child (AP view)

A sessile bony outgrowth (green overlay) can be seen on the lateral metaphysis of the femur. The cartilage cap is irregular and shows arch-like calcifications.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone-forming tumor that arises from osteoblasts, and it may manifest with progressive, dull pain. However, osteosarcomas develop more commonly in the metaphyses of long bones than the pelvis. In addition, x-ray findings typically show a sclerotic lesion and/or a periosteal reaction, which can result in a Codman triangle and/or sunburst appearance. Moreover, osteosarcomas typically develop during adolescence (peak incidence of 10–20 years of age) or more advanced age (70–80 years). Finally, histopathologic findings in osteosarcoma typically show pleomorphic osteoblasts and woven bone matrix, which are not seen here.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of the bone marrow of the lateral epicondyle of the femur (van Gieson's stain)

The atypical, polymorphic, mesenchymal cells (green overlay), which synthesize the reticular osteoid (blue overlay), are characteristic for osteosarcoma.

E) CORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma is a malignant tumor that arises from chondrocytes. It is most common in men ≥ 50 years of age and is usually a slow-growing tumor. Common sites of involvement include the pelvis, ribs, proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Manifestations include insidious, dull, deep pain that worsens at night and localized swelling with tenderness to palpation, as seen in this patient. X-ray findings typically show a moth-eaten (lytic) appearance with popcorn-like (spiculated) calcifications. The diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, which typically shows irregularly shaped lobules of cartilage, fibrous bands, and calcium deposits. Surgery, which may be curative depending on the grade, extension, and location of the tumor, is the treatment of choice.
Image Description:

X-ray hips (AP view) of patient with left hip pain, swelling, gait instability, and restriction of movement

A mixed lytic and blastic lesion in the left hemipelvis is accompanied by a large soft tissue component. Indistinct margins and areas of cortical destruction suggest an aggressive lesion.

Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma is an aggressive, malignant bone tumor that arises from neuroectodermal cells. It is commonly located on the pelvis, resulting in progressive pelvic pain that worsens at night. However, Ewing sarcoma more commonly develops in children and adolescents (peak incidence of 10–15 years of age) than adults. In addition, x-ray findings usually show periosteum with an onion skin appearance. Moreover, histopathologic findings in Ewing sarcoma typically show anaplastic, small blue cells that resemble lymphocytes, which are not seen here.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows atypical, irregularly shaped lobules of cartilage separated by fibrous bands.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old female basketball player presents with pain around the knee that has not responded to antiinflammatory drugs. A plain radiograph reveals a lesion in the metaphysis of the femur (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma is typically associated with an onion-skin periosteal reaction.

B) INCORRECT:

Enchondromas are lytic lesions that usually contain calcified chondroid matrix.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteoid osteomas are typically small and have an osteolytic center.

D) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomas typically manifest with multiple osteolytic areas in the bone.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s radiograph shows a periosteal reaction, known as Codman triangle, and ossification in a pattern perpendicular to the surface of the bone, known as a sunburst pattern. These findings are consistent with an osteosarcoma that has extended to the soft tissue.

Osteosarcomas generally arise in the metaphysis of the bone and are characterized by lytic and blastic features in admixed bone. They can be detected on plain films, CT scans, and MRIs and diagnosed via percutaneous core needle biopsy. Because osteosarcomas typically metastasize to the lungs, CT of the chest is warranted at the time of diagnosis.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young adult with a destructive bony lesion near the knee and radiographic findings consistent with a sunburst pattern is osteosarcoma.

questions.text:
A young man, 18 years of age, presents with pain in his leg that is not relieved by aspirin or ibuprofen. Plain-film radiograph of the lower leg is obtained (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteosarcomas typically affect the metaphyses of the long bones and usually occur with few symptoms. Radiographic findings include a spiculated appearance and Codman triangles, which are triangles of reactive bone formed at the edges of the penetrating lesion by the periosteum.

B) INCORRECT:

Stress fractures, chronic osteomyelitis, and osteoid osteoma all cause cortical proliferation without cortical destruction. The imaging features in this case are not consistent with stress fracture.

C) INCORRECT:

Stress fractures, chronic osteomyelitis, and osteoid osteoma all cause cortical proliferation without cortical destruction. The imaging features in this case are not consistent with chronic osteomyelitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Stress fractures, chronic osteomyelitis, and osteoid osteoma all cause cortical proliferation without cortical destruction. Pain caused by osteoid osteomas (which may be present for years) is typically relieved by aspirin or nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs.

E) CORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma is most common in children and adolescents. These tumors usually affect the shaft of the bone in an infiltrative pattern called onion skinning, which is easily visible on imaging. They tend to manifest with constitutional symptoms.

Key learning point: A sclerotic lesion with an onion-skin periosteal reaction is indicative of Ewing sarcoma.

questions.text:
A young man, 18 years of age, presents to the emergency department after sustaining a fall from a standing position. After the fall, he had severe pain in his left thigh and was unable to get up or bear weight on his left leg. He denies a history of pain or other symptoms in the thigh.
On examination, his left thigh is misaligned. A plain-film radiograph is obtained (figure).
The leg is stabilized, and the patient is admitted to the orthopedic service.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that develops in teenagers and young adults and often arises near the metaphyses of bones, with the distal femur being the most common location. However, osteochondromas rarely cause pathologic fractures; in addition, they generally appear as a spur arising from the external surface of the bone and pointing away from the joint. The clinical presentation and imaging features in this case are not consistent with an osteochondroma.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s radiograph demonstrates a metaphyseal fracture with an intramedullary sclerotic lesion. The metaphysis is the transitional zone at which the diaphysis (shaft) and epiphysis (end) of a bone come together. A metaphyseal fracture in a child or young adult should prompt evaluation for the underlying cause, such as a primary bone tumor.

A biopsy is the initial surgical procedure for any suspected bone tumor. It should ideally be performed by an orthopedic oncologist and should take place before surgical intervention for the fracture, because the result will guide the subsequent surgical approach.

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary bone tumor affecting children and young adults. The most common sites of osteosarcoma in children are the metaphyses of long bones, especially the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.

Key learning point: Fracture in a long bone of a young adult should prompt evaluation for osteosarcoma, the most common primary bone tumor affecting children and young adults.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis and osteomalacia are unlikely causes of a femoral fracture in an 18-year-old with no history of malnutrition, and the radiograph does not have features that would indicate osteomalacia.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis and osteomalacia are unlikely causes of a femoral fracture in an 18-year-old with no history of malnutrition, and the radiograph does not have features that would indicate osteomalacia.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypophosphatasia is a genetic disorder in the gene encoding alkaline phosphatase; patients present with dental and bone complaints, but sclerotic lesions are not usually seen.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl presents with right-knee pain and swelling that started about 3 months ago, after she slid into second base during a softball game. The pain, which waxes and wanes but has persisted since the injury, responds to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory therapy. The patient is concerned because her knee has continued to grow in size, and walking has become increasingly difficult. She has had no fevers or pain in other joints.
Examination of the right leg reveals tenderness to palpation, and the right knee is swollen and warm without any erythema or bruising. The patient is unable to fully extend the right knee. Examination of the left leg is normal.
A radiograph of the right leg is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following clinical or radiographic factors provides the most direct clue to this patient's likely diagnosis?

choices.text: The report of tenderness to palpation
The history of pain following trauma
The response to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medication
The appearance of the lesion on the radiograph
The swelling of the joint without bruising

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This clinical sign is unspecific.

B) INCORRECT:

This clinical sign is unspecific.

C) INCORRECT:

This clinical sign is unspecific.

D) CORRECT:

The two most common bone tumors among adolescents and young adults are osteosarcoma and Ewing sarcoma. In this patient's radiograph, the lesion of the lateral aspect of the distal femur has an irregular border with a sunburst pattern present, suggesting a malignant osteosarcoma; a Ewing sarcoma would instead have an onion-skin appearance (laminated periosteal reaction). In addition, the tumor in this patient is metaphyseal, suggesting osteosarcoma; a metadiaphyseal or diaphyseal lesion would be more suggestive of an Ewing sarcoma.

Osteosarcoma occurs primarily in the metaphysis of long bones, most often the distal femur (as in this case), proximal tibia, proximal humerus, and proximal femur. Incidence peaks during the second decade of life. Affected patients typically present with localized pain and swelling at the site of the tumor, most often the knee. The pain often starts after a traumatic event and then waxes and wanes for several months. Systemic symptoms, such as fever, are rare, and laboratory evaluations are typically normal; elevated alkaline phosphatase and lactate dehydrogenase levels are occasionally seen and are associated with a poor prognosis.

Ewing sarcoma is similar to osteosarcoma in the extent of the pain and tenderness at presentation, as well as the duration of symptoms. The main difference is the location of the tumor. Ewing sarcoma most often occurs in the pelvis and chest wall. When it occurs in the femur, it is in the diaphysis of the long bone, not the metaphysis.

Biopsy is required for the diagnosis of osteosarcoma. Because plain radiographs may underestimate the extent of disease, MRI is recommended. Bone scans and chest CT are also performed to evaluate for possible metastases. Treatment is typically a combination of chemotherapy and surgery. Time-sensitive evaluation by a specialist is indicated in order to obtain tissue biopsy for diagnosis and to initiate therapy.

Key learning point: The most common radiographic appearance of an osteosarcoma in adolescents and young adults is a sunburst lesion of the metaphysis.

E) INCORRECT:

This clinical sign is unspecific.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents with pain in his leg that is not relieved by aspirin or ibuprofen. Plain-film radiograph of the lower leg is obtained (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteosarcomas typically affect the metaphyses of the long bones and usually occur with few symptoms. Radiographic findings include a spiculated appearance and Codman triangles, which are triangles of reactive bone formed at the edges of the penetrating lesion by the periosteum.

B) INCORRECT:

Stress fractures, chronic osteomyelitis, and osteoid osteoma all cause cortical proliferation without cortical destruction. Pain caused by osteoid osteomas (which may be present for years) is typically relieved by aspirin or nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs.

C) INCORRECT:

Stress fractures, chronic osteomyelitis, and osteoid osteoma all cause cortical proliferation without cortical destruction. The imaging features in this case are not consistent with stress fracture.

D) INCORRECT:

Stress fractures, chronic osteomyelitis, and osteoid osteoma all cause cortical proliferation without cortical destruction. The imaging features in this case are not consistent with chronic osteomyelitis.

E) CORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma is most common in children and adolescents. These tumors usually affect the shaft of the bone in an infiltrative pattern called onion skinning, which is easily visible on imaging. They tend to manifest with constitutional symptoms.

Key learning point: A sclerotic lesion with an onion-skin periosteal reaction is indicative of Ewing sarcoma.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy with osteosarcoma of the right femur underwent limb-sparing surgery and completed therapy with methotrexate, doxorubicin, and cisplatin. His treatment course was complicated by a joint infection, which required ongoing treatment with rifampin and doxycycline, and by acute methotrexate toxicity with seizure, for which he now takes levetiracetam 500 mg twice daily. On routine disease evaluation 6 months after completing therapy, he was found to have recurrent disease with numerous pulmonary metastases involving both lungs but no evidence of local recurrence. His oncology team has recommended a new chemotherapy regimen of ifosfamide and etoposide.
What additional action should be taken for this patient at this time?

choices.text: Recommend that the patient stop attending school
Refer for amputation above the right knee
Increase the dose of levetiracetam to 750 mg twice daily

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s recurrent osteosarcoma is associated with high mortality, and he should be referred to palliative care, if available, in addition to starting his new chemotherapy regimen.

Approximately one-third of patients with osteosarcoma will have recurrent disease. Overall 10-year survival after recurrence of osteosarcoma is about 15%. Even for patients who will go on to die from their disease, second-line chemotherapy may provide additional months of high-quality life.

Palliative care specialists serve many roles for patients facing serious illness. These roles include identifying and managing physical and psychological symptoms, providing support for spiritual distress, using expert communication skills to identify patient and family goals, assisting with difficult decisions, and coordinating complex care. Importantly, referral to palliative care specialists is not reserved for dying patients. In fact, early referral to palliative care is best for patients, and many institutions are introducing palliative care at the time a patient receives a life-limiting medical diagnosis. Optimal palliative care teams are multidisciplinary and include physicians, advanced practice providers, nurses, social workers, chaplains, and others. The term “hospice care” refers to the system of interdisciplinary care that provides palliative care services to patients nearing the end of life.

Key learning point: Children who have cancers associated with high mortality should be offered additional cancer-directed therapies and referred for palliative care.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy has not been proven effective in the treatment of osteosarcoma. Therefore, it is not routinely recommended for patients with this disease.

C) INCORRECT:

For many children, the socialization from attending school is incredibly important. Identifying the goals and values of the patient and his family will help guide recommendations, but in general, providers should not summarily discourage children from attending school when they are able to go.

D) INCORRECT:

Amputation would not be indicated for a patient with distal metastatic disease who has no evidence of local recurrence.

E) INCORRECT:

Ifosfamide-induced neurotoxicity occurs in 10% to 30% of patients receiving this medication and typically manifests as encephalopathy. It cannot be prevented with levetiracetam, so there is no need to increase the dose of this antiseizure medication. Acute ifosfamide-induced neurotoxicity can be treated with administration of methylene blue.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents with constant, aching, thigh pain just above his right knee. The pain seems to worsen after periods of prolonged use, such as hiking, and has progressed during the past 6 months. Approximately one month ago, the patient went to an urgent care center when the pain worsened, and he was diagnosed with a muscle strain; he was prescribed a short-term nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, which alleviated the pain but only briefly. Today, he reports worsening pain and notes that his right thigh is slightly more swollen than his left, although the swelling is not limiting his range of motion. He cannot recall any trauma and does not participate in any sports or high-contact activities. He has no associated systemic symptoms.
On examination, he is afebrile. His gait is normal, and he has mild tenderness and mild swelling over the right lower thigh with normal overlying skin. The knee has normal range of motion without any redness, swelling, or effusion.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Short course of naproxen sodium twice daily
Complete blood count with measurement of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level
Plain-film radiographs of the femur and knee

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs may be considered for assistance with pain control, this patient warrants further diagnostic workup, as this is his second health care contact without resolution of symptoms during a prolonged time course.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy (PT) could be considered for a suspected strain or sprain, but this patient has no history of trauma, and his symptoms are more chronic. Thus, he should not proceed to PT without first obtaining imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

A bone scan would not adequately image the area of concern in this case and would only be indicated once malignancy is identified.

D) INCORRECT:

Laboratory testing, including a complete blood count and measurement of inflammatory markers, would be indicated if infection was suspected or if there was greater concern for leukemia. However, imaging is the more urgent intervention for this patient, who has a chronic, atraumatic history and no systemic signs of infection.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s history of gradually worsening extremity pain with no specific inciting factor should raise concern for an underlying bone malignancy. Osteosarcoma and Ewing sarcoma are the two most common bone tumors in adolescents, and both have a slight male predominance. The femur is a common site for osteosarcoma, although Ewing sarcoma can also occur there. Obtaining two-view radiographs is the best initial step to assess for either tumor. In this case, imaging is indicated given the duration of symptoms and the tenderness and swelling on examination.

Key learning point: Atraumatic, insidious extremity pain in a teenager should raise concern for bone malignancy, including osteosarcoma and Ewing sarcoma.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the office because of progressive left leg pain for the past 2 months, which has started to interfere with his sleep. One week before the pain started, the patient was hit in the thigh by a baseball, which caused his leg to become red and swollen for several days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows marked tenderness along the left mid-femur. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 68 mm/h. An x-ray of the left lower extremity shows multiple lytic lesions in the middle third of the femur, and the surrounding cortex is covered by several layers of new bone. A biopsy of the left femur shows small round blue cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteosarcoma typically occurs in the long bones of individuals between 10–20 years of age and presents similarly, with painful swelling and progressive symptoms over the course of a few weeks to months. However, osteosarcoma usually arises at the metaphysis, has a mixed lytic-sclerotic appearance, and involves an aggressive periosteal reaction with perpendicular new bone growth (resulting in a sunburst pattern and/or Codman's triangle) and irregular cortical destruction. A biopsy would reveal poorly formed trabecular bone.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP and lateral views) of a patient with osteosarcoma

An ill-defined cloud-like lesion with a wide zone of transition (green overlay) is seen in the distal femur. An aggressive type of periosteal reaction known as a Codman triangle (C) is visible medially. Additional aggressive periosteal reaction seen posteriorly has produced a sunburst pattern (S).

B) INCORRECT:

Osteochondroma typically presents as a painless bone swelling in the metaphyses of long bones, rather than the diaphysis as seen here. An x-ray would reveal a metaphyseal bony protrusion with variable degrees of sclerosis and a cartilaginous cap.
Image Description:

Bony exostosis on the lateral right distal tibial metaphysis and deformation of the right fibula

C) INCORRECT:

Chondroblastoma typically affects patients < 20 years old, appears as a lytic lesion in a long bone on x-ray, and may present with pain and swelling due to associated edema. However, chondroblastoma almost always occurs in the epiphysis and appears as single lytic lesions with well-defined margins that typically have a solid periosteal reaction (unlike the multiple diaphyseal lytic lesions and lamellated periosteal reaction seen here). Symptoms are more indolent and progress slowly over a period of 1–2 years. A biopsy would show a bluish chondroid matrix and a characteristic “chicken-wire” calcification, which is caused by calcium deposition around the chondroblasts.
Image Description:

X-ray of the right talocrural joint (a. AP view; b. lateral view)

An oval osteolytic lesion is visible in the posterolateral part of the distal tibial epiphysis.

This is the typical appearance of chondroblastoma.

D) CORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma typically occurs in patients < 20 years of age and involves the diaphysis of long bones. An x-ray usually reveals a tumor with multiple lytic lesions that may extend into the surrounding soft tissue and an aggressive lamellated periosteal reaction, giving rise to the classic onion skin appearance on x-ray (see “Overview of primary malignant bone tumors” table). A biopsy reveals small, round undifferentiated cells that appear dark blue on an H&E stain because these cells have a large nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, and the nucleus stains blue with hematoxylin. Patients also often have systemic features such as fever, ↑ ESR, and leukocytosis. A t(11;22) chromosomal translocation is found in approximately 90% of cases of Ewing sarcoma, resulting in expression of fusion protein EWS-FLI 1.
Image Description:

X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcoma

A lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

E) INCORRECT:

Osteoid osteoma typically affects patients < 30 years old in the diaphysis of a long bone and typically presents with nocturnal pain. However, an x-ray would usually show a single lytic nidus (< 2 cm in size) surrounded by a dense sclerotic reaction (unlike the multiple lytic lesions and lamellated periosteal reaction seen here). Also, pain would be relieved dramatically by aspirin or NSAIDs such as ibuprofen (since pain is caused by prostaglandins produced in the nidus).
Image Description:

X-ray right hip (AP view) of a 12-year-old boy

A small lucent nidus (hatched green overlay) in the medial proximal femur is accompanied by reactive sclerosis and cortical thickening (green overlay).

The appearance is compatible with osteoid osteoma, although other conditions (e.g., intracortical abscess, stress fracture, osteoblastoma) can mimic osteoid osteoma and must be distinguished on the basis of the clinical presentation and additional imaging.
questions.hint: Genetic testing of the biopsy sample will likely reveal a t(11;22) chromosomal translocation.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with progressive right knee pain for the past 3 months. He reports that the pain is worse at night and while doing sports at school. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee shows mild swelling and tenderness without warmth or erythema; the range of motion is limited. He walks with an antalgic gait. Laboratory studies show an alkaline phosphatase of 180 U/L and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 80 mm/h. An x-ray of the right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteoclastoma may also manifest with pain and swelling of a long bone, but it usually occurs in patients 20–40 years of age. Although the tumor may be located in the metaphysis, as in this patient, the epiphysis is typically involved, with the tumor lying in close proximity to the articular surface. An x-ray would also reveal a large, expansile lytic lesion with a thin layer of cortex and a loculated or “soap-bubble” appearance within the tumor due to trabecular remnants. The periosteal reaction would also not be as aggressive as what is seen in this patient's x-ray.
Image Description:

X-ray left knee (AP view) of a 23-year-old patient with a giant cell tumor (osteoclastoma)

A lucent lesion in the proximal tibia (green overlay) has a bubbly appearance (examples indicated by outlines) and well-defined nonsclerotic margins. The cortex shows endosteal scalloping (examples indicated by arrowheads). The growth plate is closed and the lesion extends to the subarticular bone.

Giant cell tumor is one of several bone lesions that can have a bubbly appearance. Most giant cell tumors are eccentrically located, although large lesions may appear central. They are typically located at the ends of the long bones in the region of the closed growth plate. Some giant cell tumors contain aneurysmal bone cyst components.

B) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma occurs in patients younger than 20 years of age and manifests similarly, with painful swelling that is exacerbated at night, increased ESR, increased alkaline phosphatase, and an aggressive periosteal reaction. However, the tumor typically occurs in the diaphysis of long bones, and an x-ray would reveal a tumor with multiple lytic lesions and a lamellated periosteal reaction (giving rise to an onion skin appearance on x-ray), in contrast to the mixed lytic-sclerotic lesion with a sunburst periosteal reaction.
Image Description:

X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcoma

A lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

C) INCORRECT:

Osteochondroma is the most common primary benign bone tumor. While it is more common among males 10–20 years of age, it typically manifests as a painless bone swelling near the ends of long bones. Inflammatory markers, such as ESR, are usually not increased. An x-ray would reveal a bony protrusion with variable degrees of sclerosis and a cartilaginous cap.
Image Description:

X-ray of the right upper arm

Patchy, calcified, mushroom-shaped exostosis on the surface of the humerus.
Displacement of the adjacent soft tissue (arrows) without infiltration (sharp demarcation).

D) INCORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma also often occurs in the metaphysis of long bones such as the femur and may manifest as a painful swelling. However, chondrosarcoma usually occurs in patients older than 50 years. An x-ray typically shows a focal osteolytic lesion with characteristic ring and arcs or popcorn calcifications and/or endosteal scalloping.
Image Description:

X-ray hips (AP view) of patient with left hip pain, swelling, gait instability, and restriction of movement

A mixed lytic and blastic lesion in the left hemipelvis is accompanied by a large soft tissue component. Indistinct margins and areas of cortical destruction suggest an aggressive lesion.

Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma.

E) CORRECT:

Osteosarcoma typically occurs in adolescents and young adults and involves the metaphysis of long bones. Patients present with swelling and pain that is worse at night and during activity. Decreased range of motion and gait abnormalities are also common. X-ray usually reveals a poorly defined lytic-sclerotic tumor at the metaphysis with irregular cortical destruction and an aggressive periosteal reaction with perpendicular new bone growth, resulting in a sunburst pattern and/or Codman triangle (see “Overview of primary malignant bone tumors” table). Alkaline phosphatase is often elevated in patients with osteosarcoma and is considered a poor prognostic marker.

The initial workup of this patient involves a contrast-enhanced MRI of the affected bone followed by a core needle or surgical biopsy for histological diagnosis. A chest CT, as well as a PET scan or a bone scan, should be performed to look for metastases. Definitive therapy consists of wide surgical resection of the tumor.
questions.hint: This patient's age and the location and radiological features of his bone lesion (i.e., mixed osteosclerotic and osteolytic lesion in the metaphyses) raise concern for the most common primary bone malignancy.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-month history of severe right hip pain. The pain is worse at night. He has chronic headaches and back pain for which he takes vitamin D, calcium supplements, and ibuprofen. Examination shows hip tenderness and mild sensorineural hearing loss. Laboratory studies show an increased alkaline phosphatase level. X-ray of the hip shows a radiolucent lesion in the ilium with a moth-eaten appearance, wide transition zone, and an aggressive periosteal reaction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma commonly affects the axial skeleton (including the pelvis), has a peak incidence at 50–70 years, and would cause radiolucent lesions on x-ray. This patient's history of chronic back pain, chronic headaches (skull involvement), and hearing loss (SNHL) are also consistent with the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. However, multiple myeloma would appear as well-defined (narrow transition zone) lesions on x-ray with a punched-out appearance and minimal periosteal reaction.

B) INCORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma is associated with PDB, often affects the pelvis, can appear as an ill-defined (wide transition zone), radiolucent lesion with a moth-eaten appearance and aggressive periosteal reaction as seen here.
